events.name: Poll
events.text: You've decided ot take a poll to gauge opinions about your campaign. Choose the questions you would like to include below.

events.name: Ice Cream Social
events.text: You will be passing out vanilla ice cream, giving it to students coming in and out of the building.

events.name: Community Service
events.text: You've decided to help the community by collecting food for the poor and needy.
events.results: The voters really responded to your charm and you did a great job of endorsing your platform.

events.name: Compete in Game Tournament
events.text: You want to join and play video game tournament at Mars U. Hoping you will become more popular with the students.

events.name: Create Posters
events.text: Going to the Arts college, you decide to work on the posters for your campaign. You also hope to spend time with Arts students.

events.name: Mars U Sports Game
events.text: It is time to support out local floozball team! Please go to the gazorb field and cheer your hearts out!

events.name: Study in the Library
events.text: It is time to sit down and have some peace and quiet, or study with a group of students.

events.name: Test Students Programs
events.text: The technology students want you to try their computer programs. You will need to give them feedback on their programs.

events.name: Go to a Party
events.text: You want to go hangout with your friends and party after dealing with a long week. It's a good time to say hello and become more famous.

events.name: Charity Event
events.text: Certain voters need some prove that you have their interests at hearts. So, why don't you stop by a club to show that your interests connect with theirs.

events.name: Meet the Robotics Team
events.text: You need to talk to the Robotics Team about their current project and their plans.

events.name: Meet the Debate Team
events.text: You want to talk to the Debate Team about what their current plans. You want to find out how they're doing in competitions.

events.name: Visit the Tech Lab
events.text: You want to come by and look at all the projects that are being created in the Tech Lab.
events.results: You managed to sway a lot of people to your side with your quick witted responses.

events.name: Help Paint Mural
events.text: You want to help the Arts students work on the giant mural. Art students have been working on the giant mural all semester.

events.name: Work Out
events.text: It is time to work out at the gym. You need to lose some weight and get to know the students.

events.name: Book Drive
events.text: Let's help the library out and get some more books in the library.

events.name: Promote Club Activities
events.text: It's that time of year - Club Fair! Help clubs organize and promote themselves to get new members.

events.name: Coffee Run
events.text: Time for some coffee, but it’s during the busiest time of the day. You gotta run and get there fast!

events.name: Photobomb
events.text: Let’s take pictures with everyone and post them on your MyFace account!

events.name: Secret Sticker
events.text: You want students to support your side. You need to give them a sticker.

events.name: Mean Moves
events.text: Time to bust a move to those dance moves!

events.name: T-Shirt Canon
events.text: Who doesn’t like free t-shirts? Let’s give some out!

questions.question: What issue are you most in favor of?
What issue are you most in opposition to?

What candidate are you most in opposition to?
What is your economic class?

How do you feel about this issue?
How much do you know this candidate?

questions.question: How trustworthy do you think this candidate is?
questions.labels: Very Untrustworthy, Untrustworthy, Sort of Trustworthy, Fairly Trustworthy, Very Trustworthy

tutorialPages.title: How To Play
tutorialPages.content: Hi, my name is Gui’De. I will help you find your way around Mars University. You’re a new student, and we need your help now. It’s time for the student president election and all the candidates won't do a good job. You should run for president of the Student Council!

tutorialPages.title: Areas
tutorialPages.content: Lets Take a Tour of the school! There are five main places on the Mars U Campus. Each area attracts different people to them.

tutorialPages.title: Areas - Bias
tutorialPages.content:
Here is where everybody can be found!
Commons: Socialites and Arts Majors
Library: Readers and Law Majors
Gym: Athletes and Business Majors
Labs: Gamers and Technology Majors

tutorialPages.title: Candidates
tutorialPages.content: Like in any election you'll have some comptetition. There are five other people running for presisdent at Mars U.

tutorialPages.title: Candidates - Issue Candidates
tutorialPages.content:
There are four candidates who don't do much campaigning. We call them the issue candidates. They're pretty well know and liked around campus so they think they don't need to campaign. Here are the Candidates in there issues.
Simon: Improve Medical Services
Zrapp: Increase the Budget
Boof: Lower Tuition
C1AMP: More School Functions

tutorialPages.title: Candidates - Karma
tutorialPages.content: The final candidate also transferred in recently. Karma the Chameleon is very charismatic, but isn't very well known. People like her, but they have noticed that she seems to copy the statements of other candidates.

tutorialPages.title: Statements and Functions
tutorialPages.content:
You can win by doing three things:
-Statements
-Polling
-Student Functions
You have 12 hours in a day and everything you do takes time.

tutorialPages.title: Statements
tutorialPages.content: Statements are where you focus on the issues at school. Statements can change the way people feel about the issues. They also tell the population how you feel about the issues.

tutorialPages.title: Statements - Continued
tutorialPages.content: People are more likely to vote for you if they agree with you on the issues. Be sure to stick to one stance on each issue, because people won't like it if they can't trust you. Statements take an hour to prepare and perform.

tutorialPages.title: Issues
Student Functions
tutorialPages.content: Student Functions are how you get to know the population. Becoming more famous among groups to help get you elected.

tutorialPages.title: Student Functions - Continued
tutorialPages.content: Functions take a couple hours to set up and you can add an option to that if you like, but it will take an extra hour. Functions can't be held in the quad according to the Univerity Guidelines.

tutorialPages.title: Population - Majors
Population - Social Groups
Polling
tutorialPages.content: With polls you can see how the populations around the school feel about the candidates, and issues. You take polls in different areas which will have different biases.

tutorialPages.title: Polling - Continued
tutorialPages.content: Polls take time to conduct, but the current student government will conduct one for you at the end of each day. These will help you see your effect on the population.

tutorialPages.title: Polling Results
tutorialPages.content: After you take a poll you are given the results from a sample of students. By looking at these results you can determine what moves you should make next. Poll Results can be viewed in 3 ways: Bar Graphs, Pie Graphs and a Table.

tutorialPages.title: Polling Results - Graphs
tutorialPages.content: The Bar and Pie Graphs are for looking at more general data. Each Graph is attributed to a question. There you can see how many students answered each result in a question.

tutorialPages.title: Polling Results - Table
tutorialPages.content: The table is for when you want specific data. In the table you can see how each person who took the sample responded to all the questions. You can even filter by majors, or social groups. So if you only want results from athletes then you can just view those.

tutorialPages.title: Old Polling Reports
tutorialPages.content: Poll Results are saved for you after you take them so you can go back and view them at the poll menu whenever you like.

tutorialPages.title: Trend Reports
tutorialPages.content: If you ask the same question more than once, it will appear on the trend report. A place where you can see the summary of all the graphs for that question. This is great for looking quickly at how public opinion has changed.

tutorialPages.title: Help Pages
tutorialPages.content: You can return here later or use the help button displayed above to open the help page related to the page you are currently on. From that page you can navigate through the help menu to any other help page or return to the page you were on. I've created when you have questions.

tutorialPages.title: Practice Area
tutorialPages.content: After this tutorial you will enter a practice polling area where you can create polls and look at polling results. Try it out, but remember, the data does not represent the actual students or candidates. You can start your election or return to the tutorial at any time.
